title: Body Acceptance
description: Explore how accepted you feel in your body within your relationship

questions.text: I feel accepted by my partner exactly as I am physically.

therapeutic.rationale: Physical acceptance—feeling your body is welcomed as it is—creates safety for intimacy. Conditional acceptance based on appearance undermines this foundation.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel accepted, explore what creates that feeling. Comments? Looks? Comparisons? The other partner needs to know.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual physical acceptance creates freedom to be present in your bodies together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you feel your body is accepted as it is? What affects that feeling?

questions.text: My partner's way of looking at me makes me feel good about my body.

therapeutic.rationale: How your partner looks at you communicates acceptance or judgment. A loving gaze can heal body image wounds; a critical gaze can deepen them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner's gaze doesn't feel good, explore what they're perceiving. Sometimes it's about the receiver's interpretation; sometimes the giver needs awareness.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual experience of affirming gazes strengthens body confidence in your relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner look at you? What does their gaze communicate?

questions.text: I don't feel I need to hide parts of my body from my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: Hiding parts of your body signals shame or fear of judgment. When you can be fully seen without needing to hide, intimacy can be more complete.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner hides parts of themselves, approach with compassion. This often connects to deeper body image issues that deserve gentle attention.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual freedom from hiding creates full physical presence with each other.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Are there parts of yourself you hide from your partner? What would help you feel safer?

questions.text: My partner seems comfortable with my body, including its imperfections.

therapeutic.rationale: Perceiving your partner's comfort with your imperfections allows you to relax. Sensing discomfort—real or imagined—creates self-consciousness.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't sense comfort with their imperfections, the other can express acceptance more clearly. Sometimes silence is misread as judgment.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of comfort with each other's imperfections creates acceptance.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner respond to your physical imperfections?

questions.text: Being with my partner helps me appreciate my own body more.

therapeutic.rationale: Relationships can heal or harm body image. When your partner's love helps you appreciate your body, intimacy becomes a source of healing.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner's body image isn't helped by the relationship, explore what would help. More verbal appreciation? Different types of touch?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual body appreciation through your relationship is a gift you give each other.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How has your relationship affected how you feel about your body?
